questions.question: You arrive in Utopia, a seemingly perfect society. You are greeted by its people, and everything appears idyllic. Days pass, and you begin to settle into your new life. As you become more integrated into the system, the voice of your past haunts you: 'You allowed humanity to fall from paradise. Is this not the second chance you sought? A perfect society of perfect humans' Yet doubts grow. What will you do?

choices.text: You appreciate the society and wish to stay

questions.question: Staying in Utopia is much easier than getting out. Easily, you survive. You move day in, day out through your duties. But, living there is much harder.
You decide to leave, but Utopia does not make it easy. What's your plan?

choices.text: Lie low, gathering time to plan your escape.

questions.question: The very first person you talk to reports you. Unfortunate, but now, you are on Utopia's watchlist and are never ever leaving.
Rushing out to the countryside, you are quickly captured by Utopian officials and put to death for trying to escape.

You lie low. You integrate. You slowly become used to your new life and find comfort in your routine. What is a couple weeks or months? You have friends here now and a purpose in society. Do you still plan your escape?

choices.text: Yes. I still want to get out.

questions.question: You resolute yourself to your goal. Trying to do this the official way, you walk out, seeking to ask Utopian officials to travel and use that as a means of escape. However, when walking, you see a penny face up. That is good luck. Do you pick it up?

Immediately, the Utopian government, who sees all, grabs you. Your own penny! You clearly haven't given up ownership of property. You have been on thin ice, but now, for a lucky penny, you are put to death.

Without picking up the penny, you approach a Utopian officer and resolutely request permission to travel. As he studies you carefully, you brace yourself for questions about your destination, companions, and reasons for leaving. However, you are unprepared for the officer's unexpected inquiry about a secret entrusted to you by your only friends in Utopia. Why would he be interested in such a seemingly harmless secret? Should you reveal it, or honor your friendship and keep it safe?

The officer, unimpressed with you, sniffles before saying that such attachment to people is individualistic for there is no reason to hold such unhealthy attachment. Therefore, your request has been denied and so will all future ones. Enjoy life in Utopia.

You pass and are allowed to travel, letting you escape. But at what price? You reflect on the penny and the secret. Such small, silly details could have cost you your life. But, why could you not keep them? You notice how, when trying to fit in the perfect society, you become less human. You carry the weight of a missing penny and lost secret for the rest of your life- or at least, what you hope is a life.
